column1: Kirkland was the original home of the Seattle Seahawks; the NFL team's headquarters and training facility were located at the Lake Washington Shipyard (now Carillon Point) along Lake Washington for their first ten seasons (1976–85)
column2: then at nearby Northwest University through 2007. Warehouse chain Costco previously had its headquarters in Kirkland. While Costco is now headquartered in Issaquah
column3: the city is the namesake of its "Kirkland Signature" store brand.

column1: The land around Lake Washington to the east of Seattle was first settled by Native Americans. English settlers arrived in the late 1860s
column2: when the McGregor and Popham families built homesteads in what is now the Houghton neighborhood. Four miles (6 km) to the north people also settled near what is now called Juanita Bay
column3: a favored campsite of the Natives because a wild potato
column4: "wapatos"
column5: thrived there. The Curtis family arrived in the area in the 1870s
column6: followed by the French family in 1872. The Forbes family homesteaded what is now Juanita Beach Park in 1876
column7: and settled on Rose Hill in 1877. Gradually
column8: additional people settled in the area
column9: and by the end of the 1880s a small number of logging
column10: farming and boat-building communities were established.

column3: a British-born enterprising businessman seeking to expand the family's Moss Bay steel production company
column4: moved to Washington after hearing that iron deposits had been discovered in the Cascade Range. Other necessary components such as limestone
column5: needed in steel smelting
column6: were readily available in the area. Further yet
column7: a small number of coal mines (a required fuel source for steel mills) had recently been established nearby in Newcastle and train lines were already under construction. Plans were also underway to build the Lake Washington Ship Canal.

column3: Kirk and Hunt purchased thousands of acres of land in what is now Kirkland's downtown in July 1888. Kirk and his associates started the construction of a new steel mill soon after
column4: named the Moss Bay Iron and Steel Company of America. After founding the city of Kirkland in 1888
column5: officially one of the earliest on the Eastside at the time

column1: In 1900 the Curtis family made a living operating a ferry-construction business on Lake Washington. Along with Captain John Anderson
column2: the Curtises were among the first to run ferries in the area. Leschi
column3: first operated on December 27
column5: was the original wooden ferry to transport automobiles and people between the Eastside and Madison Park until her retirement in 1950. The ferry operations ran nearly continuously for 18 hours each day. The construction of the first Lake Washington floating bridge in 1940
column6: however
column7: made ferry service unprofitable and eventually led to its cancellation. Subsequent years saw wool milling and warship building become the major industries.

column1: The first woolen mill in the state of Washington was built in Kirkland in 1892. The mill was the primary supplier of wool products for the Alaska Gold Rush prospectors and for the U.S. military during World War I. By 1917
column2: after the completion of the Lake Washington Ship Canal
column3: the construction of ocean-going vessels had become a major business. By 1940
column4: the thriving Lake Washington Shipyard had constructed more than 25 warships during World War II for the U.S. Navy
column5: on what is now Carillon Point.

column1: Kirkland had a gallery district downtown until recent years when all but three galleries closed or moved away.  The Kirkland Performance Center hosts a number of performing arts events. The Kirkland Arts Center
column2: located in the historic Peter Kirk Building on Market Street

column1: Kirkland hosted the annual Kirkland Concours d'Elegance at Carillon Point from 2003 until 2011
column2: showing vintage and classic automobiles (and wooden boats) from across the country. The Porsche Club of America now hosts an annual Porsche car show at the Carillon Point location every September.

column1: The Kirkland Teen Union Building (KTUB) in downtown Peter Kirk Park is supported by the city and a number of nonprofit organizations.  It has two music stages

column1: The local Lake Washington High School lacrosse team defeated intercity rival Juanita High School in the state championship 8–7 in 2015 to secure a state title.
The Lake Washington High school Baseball team won the first ever State Championship (3A) in school history during 2016
They won a State Championship (3A) once again in 2019
column2: defeating O’Dea 3-1. Kirkland FC is an amateur soccer club in the Western Washington Premier League
column3: which began play in 2018. They are referred to as the Goats.

column1: Kirkland was the original home of the Seattle Seahawks; the NFL team's headquarters and training facility were located at the Lake Washington Shipyard (now Carillon Point) along Lake Washington for their first ten seasons (1976–85)

column1: Kirkland has two Little Leagues: Kirkland American Little League and Kirkland National Little League. Kirkland National won the 1982 Little League World Series championship. They defeated a team from Taiwan 6–0 on August 28
column2: 1982.The Kirkland Baseball Commission provides recreational baseball for players ages 13–18. It is affiliated with the national Pony Baseball organization.

column1: The 1982 Kirkland National Little League team won the Little League World Series in Williamsport
column2: Pennsylvania. That event is the subject of the ESPN 30 for 30 documentary Little Big Men. It also was the home to Little League's 1992 Big League Softball World Series Champions representing the Eastside District Nine Leagues. Since 1999
column3: Kirkland has been the home of the Little League Junior Softball World Series held each August at Kirkland's Everest Park.

column2: residents of neighboring cities flock to Kirkland to visit Kirkland's many waterfront parks on Lake Washington. Kirkland has neighborhood parks as well
column3: contains a corner of Saint Edward State Park
column4: and abuts the equestrian Bridle Trails State Park. The waterfront parks are linked by a paved trail
column5: which is open until dusk. Juanita Beach Park is another major park in Kirkland
column6: and is a tourist attraction. The Cross Kirkland Corridor is a rail-trail that roughly bisects the city.

column1: Kirkland has a council–manager form of government
column2: with a city manager hired by the city council. The seven councilmembers are elected at-large for staggered four-year terms in non-partisan elections. The city council selects a mayor from among its members
column3: who serves as council chair but has no veto power. As of 2019
column4: the mayor is Penny Sweet and the city manager is former King County Executive Kurt Triplett.

column4: and Sammamish. The school district operates two high schools

Kirkland was the first city in Washington to adopt a Complete Streets ordinance
column3: whereby pedestrian and bicycle facilities are addressed as a part of all road construction and improvement planning projects. Kirkland passed an Active Transportation Plan in 2009 specifically targeting improvements to pedestrian
column4: bicycle

column6: Totem Lake
column7: and South Kirkland. The city also has several park and ride facilities along Interstate 405. Buses connect Kirkland to Bellevue
column10: and Kenmore.As part of Sound Transit 3
column11: Kirkland is slated to receive a short Link light rail line from Issaquah and Downtown Bellevue that will terminate at South Kirkland Park and Ride. It is scheduled to open in 2041. The Sound Transit 3 program also includes a bus rapid transit line on Interstate 405
column12: with stops at NE 85th Street and the existing Totem Lake Freeway Station. The NE 85th Street station is projected to cost $235–300 million
column13: making it one of the most expensive bus projects under consideration by Sound Transit
column14: due to the need to completely rebuild the cloverleaf interchange. The city's existing transit center about a mile away and about 200 feet (61 m) lower in elevation could be connected with the first aerial tramway in the Seattle area. The station is planned to open in 2024 after three years of construction.

column2: a public healthcare system that operates a 318-bed hospital complex near Totem Lake. It was founded in 1967 and opened the first phase of Evergreen General Hospital in 1972.
